title: Pedro Pascal
content:
{{short description|Chilean and American actor (born 1975)}} {{for|people with a similar name|Pedro Pascual (disambiguation)}} {{pp-semi-indef|small=yes}} {{family name hatnote|Balmaceda|Pascal|lang=Spanish}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2023}} {{Use American English|date=July 2023}} {{Infobox person | name = Pedro Pascal | image = Pedro Pascal by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Pascal in 2017 | birth_name = José Pedro Balmaceda Pascal | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1975|4|2}} | birth_place = [[Santiago]], Chile | other_names = Pedro Balmaceda
Alexander Pascal | occupation = Actor | education = [[New York University]] ([[Bachelor of Fine Arts|BFA]]) | works = [[Pedro Pascal on screen and stage|Full list]] | years_active = 1996–present | relatives = [[Lux Pascal]] (sister) | signature = Pedro Pascal Signature.svg }} '''José Pedro Balmaceda Pascal''' ({{IPA|es|xoˈse ˈpeðɾo βalmaˈseða pasˈkal|lang}}; born April 2, 1975) is a Chilean and American actor. After nearly two decades of taking small roles on stage and television, Pascal had his [[breakthrough role|breakout role]] as [[Oberyn Martell]] in the [[Game of Thrones (season 4)|fourth season]] of the [[HBO]] fantasy series ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' (2014). He gained further prominence with his portrayal of [[Javier Peña]] in the [[Netflix]] crime series ''[[Narcos]]'' (2015–2017). He went on to appear in the films ''[[The Great Wall (film)|The Great Wall]]'' (2016), ''[[Kingsman: The Golden Circle]]'' (2017), ''[[The Equalizer 2]]'' (2018), and ''[[Triple Frontier (film)|Triple Frontier]]'' (2019). Pascal's leading roles as [[The Mandalorian (character)|Din Djarin]] in the [[Disney+]] science fiction series ''[[The Mandalorian]]'' (2019–2023) and [[Joel (The Last of Us)|Joel Miller]] in the HBO post-apocalyptic drama series ''[[The Last of Us (TV series)|The Last of Us]]'' (2023–present) propelled him to international stardom, earning him a reputation for portraying adoptive [[father figure]]s. For the latter role, he received numerous accolades, including a [[Screen Actors Guild Award]] and a nomination for a [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Award]] and [[Primetime Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Award]]. He also portrayed parental characters in ''[[We Can Be Heroes (2020 film)|We Can Be Heroes]]'' (2020), ''[[Strange Way of Life]]'' (2023), and ''[[The Wild Robot]]'' (2024). Pascal has also starred in the big-budget films ''[[Wonder Woman 1984]]'' (2020) and ''[[Gladiator II]]'' (2024). Active in theatre since 1999, he made his [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut as [[Edmund (King Lear)|Edmund]] in a 2019 adaptation of ''[[King Lear]]''. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine named him one of the [[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]] in 2023,{{cite news |url=https://time.com/collection/100-most-influential-people-2023/ |title=Time 100 |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=April 13, 2023 |access-date=April 13, 2023 |archive-date=April 13, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230413151502/https://time.com/collection/100-most-influential-people-2023/ |url-status=live }} and in 2024, he was polled as [[Grindr]]'s hottest man of the year.{{Cite web |date=December 5, 2024 |title=Pedro Pascal tops Jonathan Bailey in Grindr’s Hottest Man of the Year poll |url=https://www.thepinknews.com/2024/12/05/grindr-unwrapped-2024-pedro-pascal-jonathan-bailey/ |access-date=December 6, 2024 |website=[[PinkNews]] }} ==Early life== {{see also|Allende family|Balmaceda family}} José Pedro Balmaceda Pascal was born on April 2, 1975, in [[Santiago]], [[Chile]]{{Cite web |title=Pedro Pascal Profile |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/celebrity/pedro_pascal |access-date= April 2, 2022 |agency=Rotten Tomatoes|archive-date= April 2, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220402214627/https://www.rottentomatoes.com/celebrity/pedro_pascal |url-status=live }} to child psychologist Verónica Pascal Ureta and fertility doctor José Balmaceda Riera, a member of the [[Castilian-Basque aristocracy]].{{cite news |last=Ito |first=Robert |title=A Lethal Prince, Even if a Bit Clumsy: Pedro Pascal Becomes Red Viper on 'Game of Thrones' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/30/arts/television/pedro-pascal-becomes-red-viper-on-game-of-thrones.html?_r=0 |access-date= May 27, 2014 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date= March 28, 2014 |archive-date= November 12, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112020115/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/30/arts/television/pedro-pascal-becomes-red-viper-on-game-of-thrones.html?_r=0 |url-status=live}}{{cite web |last=Koblin |first=John |title=Pedro Pascal: Making It at 41 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/03/fashion/mens-style/pedro-pascal-great-wall-game-of-thrones-narcos-late-success.html |access-date= July 4, 2019 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date= February 3, 2017 |archive-date= December 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201229040531/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/03/fashion/mens-style/pedro-pascal-great-wall-game-of-thrones-narcos-late-success.html |url-status=live}} His paternal grandmother was born in [[Palma de Mallorca]], [[Spain]].{{Cite web |last=Palma |first=Redacción |date=2017-09-21 |title=El pasado mallorquín del agente Peña de Narcos |url=https://www.diariodemallorca.es/sociedad/2017/09/21/pasado-mallorquin-agente-pena-narcos-3343743.html |access-date=2023-05-30 |website=Diario de Mallorca |language=es |archive-date=May 30, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230530210555/https://www.diariodemallorca.es/sociedad/2017/09/21/pasado-mallorquin-agente-pena-narcos-3343743.html |url-status=live }} He has an older sister named Javiera,{{cite web |title="Narcos" star Pedro Pascal on the mystery of Pablo Escobar's death | date=September 2, 2016 | via=[[YouTube]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HC5G0bsSQtw |access-date= November 3, 2020 |archive-date= December 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201229040511/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HC5G0bsSQtw |url-status=live}} a younger brother named Nicolás,{{Cite web |last=Pascal |first=Pedro |date=April 10, 2019 |title=This is my brother, Nicolas. |url=https://www.instagram.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Fp%2FBwE8pfHDb4Y%2F%3Fhl%3Den |access-date=2023-07-09 |website=www.instagram.com}} and a younger sister named [[Lux Pascal|Lux]], who is an actress and [[transgender]] activist.{{cite web |url=http://www.t13.cl/noticia/entretencion/Lucas-Balmaceda-el-hermano-del-chileno-de-Game-of-Thrones-que-llego-a-remecer-Los-80 |title=Lucas Balmaceda, el hermano del chileno de Game of Thrones que llegó a remecer Los 80 |website=t13.cl |date=November 12, 2014 |access-date= January 13, 2018 |archive-date= November 11, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201111204523/https://www.t13.cl/noticia/entretencion/Lucas-Balmaceda-el-hermano-del-chileno-de-Game-of-Thrones-que-llego-a-remecer-Los-80 |url-status=live}}{{cite web |title=Pedro Pascal Sweetly Supports His Sister Lux After She Comes Out as a Trans Woman: 'Mi Corazón' |url=https://people.com/movies/pedro-pascal-supports-sister-lux-comes-out-trans-woman/ |website=People |date= February 9, 2021 |access-date= February 12, 2021 |archive-date= February 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210211212045/https://people.com/movies/pedro-pascal-supports-sister-lux-comes-out-trans-woman/ |url-status=live }} Pascal's mother was the cousin of [[Andrés Pascal Allende]], the nephew of socialist [[President of Chile|Chilean President]] [[Salvador Allende]] (through his sister [[Laura Allende|Laura]]). Pascal Allende was an early leader of the [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|Movement of the Revolutionary Left]], a militant [[far-left]] organization.{{Cite web |url=https://www.latercera.com/noticia/pedro-pascal-punto/ |title=Pedro Pascal, en su punto |website=La Tercera |date= September 1, 2017 |access-date= January 10, 2021 |archive-date= February 24, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210224073623/https://www.latercera.com/noticia/pedro-pascal-punto/ |url-status=live }} Two years before Pascal's birth, the [[Presidency of Salvador Allende|democratically elected socialist government]] of [[Salvador Allende]] was overthrown by General [[Augusto Pinochet]], leading to the country becoming a [[Military dictatorship of Chile|military dictatorship]].{{cite news |last1=Güimil |first1=Eva |title=Pedro Pascal: The trials and triumphs of the first breakout star of 2023 |url=https://english.elpais.com/culture/2023-02-24/pedro-pascal-the-trials-and-triumphs-of-the-first-breakout-star-of-2023.html |access-date=20 November 2024 |work=El País |date=24 February 2023}} Both of Pascal's parents were listed as enemies of the state by the Pinochet regime and the family eventually fled Chile when he was nine months old, after seeking refuge in the [[Venezuela]]n embassy in Santiago for six months. The family later received political asylum in [[Denmark]]{{cite web |date=November 13, 2020 |title=The Mandalorian's Pedro Pascal Credits His Success to His Mom, Who Died Before He Became Famous |url=https://people.com/tv/the-mandalorian-pedro-pascal-credits-his-success-to-his-mom/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201212035519/https://people.com/tv/the-mandalorian-pedro-pascal-credits-his-success-to-his-mom/ |archive-date=December 12, 2020 |access-date=January 1, 2021 |website=People}}{{cite news |last=Broeske |first=Pat H. |title=The Viper Prince |url=http://www.orangecoast.com/features/2014/04/28/the-viper-prince |access-date= May 27, 2014 |publisher=Orange Coast |date= April 28, 2014 |archive-date= June 2, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140602035249/http://www.orangecoast.com/features/2014/04/28/the-viper-prince |url-status=live}} before settling in the United States, where Pascal was raised in [[San Antonio, Texas]],{{cite news |last=McIntyre |first=Gina |title='Game of Thrones': Red Viper actor Pedro Pascal hates spoilers too |url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/tv/game-of-thrones-red-viper-actor-pedro-pascal-hates-spoilers-too/ |access-date= May 27, 2014 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date= May 12, 2014 |archive-date= September 8, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180908015642/https://herocomplex.latimes.com/tv/game-of-thrones-red-viper-actor-pedro-pascal-hates-spoilers-too/ }} until they relocated to [[Orange County, California]], when he was 11 years old. By the time he was eight years old, his family regularly visited Chile to see his 34 cousins.{{cite magazine |last=Vary |first=Adam B. |title=Pedro Pascal on Fame and 'The Mandalorian': 'Can We Cut the S— and Talk About the Child?' |url=https://variety.com/2020/tv/news/pedro-pascal-the-mandalorian-star-wars-wonder-woman-1984-1234803468/ |access-date= January 1, 2021 |magazine=Variety |date= October 14, 2020 |archive-date= October 15, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201015194622/https://variety.com/2020/tv/news/pedro-pascal-the-mandalorian-star-wars-wonder-woman-1984-1234803468/ |url-status=live }} His parents would ultimately move back to Chile in 1995 to raise his two younger siblings.{{Cite magazine |last=Warner |first=Kara |url=https://time.com/collection/american-voices-2017/4985811/american-voices-pedro-pascal/ |title=Pedro Pascal on His Roots in Chile and Breakout Stardom |date=October 30, 2017 |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |access-date=June 3, 2024 |archive-date=March 1, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240301121715/https://time.com/collection/american-voices-2017/4985811/american-voices-pedro-pascal/ |url-status=live }} He pursued acting at the [[Orange County School of the Arts]] and graduated in 1993, before attending [[New York University]]'s [[Tisch School of the Arts]], where he graduated in 1997.{{cite web |title=ETW Alumni |url=https://tisch.nyu.edu/drama/about/studios/experimental-theatre-wing/alumni |website=[[New York University]] |access-date= January 1, 2021 |archive-date= January 19, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210119205137/https://tisch.nyu.edu/drama/about/studios/experimental-theatre-wing/alumni |url-status=live }} After his mother's death, he began using her surname professionally as a tribute to her and because he felt that Americans had difficulty pronouncing his paternal surname, Balmaceda. == Career == === 1999–2013: Early work === {{Quote box | quote = "My vision of it was that if I didn’t have some major exposure by the time I was twenty-nine years old, it was over, so I was constantly readjusting what it meant to commit my life to this profession, and giving up the idea of it looking like I thought it would when I was a kid. There were so many good reasons to let that delusion go." | author = –Pascal on his aspirations as an actor early in his career. | width = 23.8em | align = right | bgcolor = | quoted = 1 }} Early in his career, Pascal appeared in several television series, including ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'', ''[[NYPD Blue]]'', ''[[The Good Wife]]'', ''[[Nurse Jackie]]'', and ''[[Homeland (TV series)|Homeland]]''.{{Cite web |last=Harris |first=Jeffery |url=https://collider.com/pedro-pascal-early-tv-roles/ |title=You May Not Have Recognized Pedro Pascal in Some of His Earliest Roles |date=January 22, 2024 |website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] |access-date=May 17, 2024 }} Pascal experienced hard times during that point in his career; besides working in small acting and theatre roles, he took jobs [[waiting staff|waiting]] at restaurants. Pascal admitted that he was fired "often, upwards of, I don’t know, maybe close to 10 times".{{Cite web |last=Thokchom |first=Rahul |url=https://fandomwire.com/maybe-10-times-before-gaining-fame-as-game-of-thrones-oberyn-martell-pedro-pascal-was-often-fired-from-his-job-confesses-being-biased-towards-people/ |title="Maybe 10 times": Before Gaining Fame As Game Of Thrones' Oberyn Martell Pedro Pascal Was Often Fired From His Job, Confesses Being Biased Towards People |date=September 4, 2023 |website=[[IndieWire]] |access-date=June 3, 2024 |archive-date=June 3, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240603192658/https://fandomwire.com/maybe-10-times-before-gaining-fame-as-game-of-thrones-oberyn-martell-pedro-pascal-was-often-fired-from-his-job-confesses-being-biased-towards-people/ |url-status=live }} In times of extreme hardship, Pascal's close friend [[Sarah Paulson]] would give him her [[per diem]] money "so that he could have money to feed himself."{{Cite web |last=Tinoco |first=Armando |url=https://deadline.com/2023/04/sarah-paulson-helped-pedro-pascal-early-career-giving-acting-pay-money-to-feed-himself-1235322457/ |title=Sarah Paulson Helped Pedro Pascal Early In His Career Giving Him Her Acting Pay So ""He Could Have Money To Feed Himself" |date=April 11, 2023 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |access-date=June 28, 2024 }} At a point when he found difficulty in affording medical care, only having less than seven dollars in his bank account, he received a residual check from his role in ''Buffy'', which helped him to restabilize his finances and allowed him to continue pursuing acting.{{Cite web |last=Roe |first=Mike |url=https://www.thewrap.com/pedro-pascal-buffy-the-vampire-slayer-quit-acting/ |title=Pedro Pascal Says 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer' Residual Check Saved Him From Quitting Acting |date=March 18, 2024 |website=[[TheWrap]] |access-date=June 3, 2024 |archive-date=June 3, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240603192657/https://www.thewrap.com/pedro-pascal-buffy-the-vampire-slayer-quit-acting/ |url-status=live }} Pascal is a member of New York City's [[LAByrinth Theater Company]].{{cite web |title=Company Members |url=http://www.labtheater.org/companymembers/memberslist.html |website=[[LAByrinth Theater Company]] |access-date= June 4, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019045129/http://www.labtheater.org/companymembers/memberslist.html |archive-date= October 19, 2013}} He received the Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Award and [[Back Stage Garland Awards|Garland Award]] for his role in the [[International City Theater]] production of ''Orphans'', and has performed in classical and contemporary works.{{Cite web |url=https://www.broadway.com/buzz/stars/pedro-pascal/profile/ |title=Star File – Pedro Pascal |website=broadway.com |access-date=May 20, 2024 |archive-date=May 20, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240520230202/https://www.broadway.com/buzz/stars/pedro-pascal/profile/ |url-status=live }} In 2010, he wrote a play, directed by [[Sarah Silverman]], ''Flaca Loves Bone'', about four siblings who meet in a snowy wood to uncover a family secret.{{Cite web |title=Pedro Pascal |url=https://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsP/pascal-pedro.php |access-date= February 26, 2023 |website=www.doollee.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221210015015/https://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsP/pascal-pedro.php |archive-date= December 10, 2022 |url-status=live}} Also in 2010, Pascal made his directorial debut with ''Killing Play'', written by David Anzuelo, at [[Rattlestick Playwrights Theater]].{{Cite web |title=Rattlestick Presents Seven New Works at "F*!@cking Good Plays! (festival)" |url=https://playbill.com/article/rattlestick-presents-seven-new-works-at-f-cking-good-plays-festival-com-164613 |access-date=June 3, 2024 |website=PlayBill |archive-date=June 4, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240604023405/https://playbill.com/article/rattlestick-presents-seven-new-works-at-f-cking-good-plays-festival-com-164613 |url-status=live }} He also directed ''underneathmybed'' and ''Yosemite'' there.{{Cite web |author=BWW News Desk |title=Rattlestick Playwrights' underneathmybed Closes 10/10 |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/off-broadway/article/Rattlestick-Playwrights-underneathmybed-Closes-1010-20101010 |access-date= February 26, 2023 |website=BroadwayWorld.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230226145858/https://www.broadwayworld.com/off-broadway/article/Rattlestick-Playwrights-underneathmybed-Closes-1010-20101010 |archive-date= February 26, 2023 |url-status=live}}{{Cite web |title=Rattlestick Playwrights Theater Continues Evening Reading Series With Yosemite 5/18 |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Rattlestick-Playwrights-Theater-Continues-Evening-Reading-Series-With-YOSEMITE-518-20100518 |access-date=February 26, 2023 |website=BroadwayWorld.com |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20230307180352/https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Rattlestick-Playwrights-Theater-Continues-Evening-Reading-Series-With-YOSEMITE-518-20100518 |archive-date=March 7, 2023 |url-status=live }} He was cast in the [[Pilot (TV)|pilot]] for the [[Wonder Woman (2011 TV pilot)|2011 ''Wonder Woman'' television adaptation]] as [[Ed Indelicato]], Wonder Woman's liaison to the [[LAPD]], but the show was not picked up.{{Cite web |last=Guthrie |first=Marisa |date=March 3, 2011 |title=Pedro Pascal Joins NBC's 'Wonder Woman' Pilot |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/tv/tv-news/pedro-pascal-joins-nbcs-wonder-164014/ |access-date=July 18, 2021 |website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |archive-date= July 18, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210718145651/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/tv/tv-news/pedro-pascal-joins-nbcs-wonder-164014/ |url-status=live }}{{Cite magazine |url=https://ew.com/tv/pedro-pascal-wonder-woman-pilot/ |title=Pedro Pascal briefly forgot he was in NBC's 'very risky' 'Wonder Woman' pilot |date=December 29, 2020 |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |access-date=April 7, 2023 |archive-date=April 7, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230407053606/https://ew.com/tv/pedro-pascal-wonder-woman-pilot/ |url-status=live }} === 2014–2018: Breakthrough and rise to fame === [[File:Pedro Pascal (14588037218).jpg|thumb|upright|265px|Pascal at the 2014 [[San Diego Comic Con]]]] In 2014, Pascal portrayed the character [[Oberyn Martell]] in the [[Game of Thrones (season 4)|fourth season]] of the [[HBO]]'s critically acclaimed television series ''[[Game of Thrones]]''.{{Cite web |last=Wolff |first=Natasha |date=2014-04-02 |title=Pedro Pascal Joins Game of Thrones as the Red Viper and Had "Nerd Moments," Furious About Spoilers |url=https://dujour.com/culture/pedro-pascal-red-viper-game-of-thrones/ |access-date=2023-07-13 |website=DuJour |archive-date=July 13, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230713204031/https://dujour.com/culture/pedro-pascal-red-viper-game-of-thrones/ |url-status=live }} The season aired from April 6 to June 15, 2014, and Pascal's performance as the passionate and vengeful Dornish prince garnered significant praise from both critics and audiences, with numerous publications, including ''[[CNET]]'',{{Cite web |title=Game of Thrones already lost its greatest hero: Why I loved Oberyn Martell |url=https://www.cnet.com/culture/entertainment/game-of-thrones-already-lost-its-greatest-hero-oberyn-martell/ |access-date=2023-07-13 |website=CNET |archive-date=July 13, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230713204031/https://www.cnet.com/culture/entertainment/game-of-thrones-already-lost-its-greatest-hero-oberyn-martell/ |url-status=live }} ''[[Collider (website)|Collider]]'',{{Cite web |last=Kavanagh |first=Emily |url=https://collider.com/pedro-pascal-game-of-thrones-oberyn-martell/ |title=There's a Reason Why 'Game of Thrones' Best Character Was Oberyn Martell |date=February 14, 2024 |website=[[Collider (website)|Collider]] |access-date=June 23, 2024 }} ''[[The Mary Sue]]'',{{Cite web |last1=Baranda |first1=Danielle |last2=Geddo |first2=Benedetta |url=https://www.themarysue.com/the-10-best-game-of-thrones-characters-ranked/ |title=The Best 'Game of Thrones' Characters, Ranked |date=August 12, 2023 |website=[[The Mary Sue]] |access-date=June 23, 2024 }} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'',{{Cite magazine |last=Dodds |first=Eric |url=https://time.com/2838546/game-of-thrones-why-you-cant-stop-thinking-about-oberyn-martell/ |title=Game of Thrones: Why You Can't Stop Thinking About Oberyn Martell |date=June 13, 2024 |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |access-date=June 23, 2024}} and ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' naming Martell as one of the best characters in the show.{{Cite web |last=Miller |first=Matt |url=https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/tv/g36111426/best-game-of-thrones-characters/ |title=The 25 Best Game of Thrones Characters, Ranked |date=June 7, 2024 |website=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |access-date=June 23, 2024}} ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' praised him as a [[sex symbol]] in the role, calling it "the real tipping point in his career";{{Cite web |last=Blake |first=Meredith |url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-ca-st-sunday-conversation-pedro-pascal-20170922-htmlstory.html |title=A sex symbol on 'Game of Thrones,' Pedro Pascal is having a moment with 'Narcos' and 'Kingsman' |date=September 22, 2017 |website=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=June 25, 2024 }} ''[[MovieWeb]]'' assessed that his career "skyrocket[ed]" after playing Martell.{{Cite web |last=Ghelerter |first=Adam |url=https://movieweb.com/pedro-pascal-road-to-fame/ |title=How Pedro Pascal Rose to Fame |date=March 15, 2024 |website=[[MovieWeb]] |access-date=May 17, 2024 }} Pascal stated that he was a huge fan of the show before being cast as Oberyn and was ecstatic to join.{{Cite web |last=Pedro_Pascal |date=2014-05-25 |title=I am actor Pedro Pascal.
